The grave Elizabethan house, Penshurst, within, as we

as the airman sees it as it was when in being we
should see the the farm, the cottage, roads as an
airman sees the foundations of old towns
still existing marked on the fields, we should see
the great tracks leading from the farm & the cottage;
we should see the great house as an oasis in the
in the midst of wild country;
If we could see the great house as it was when Spenser
in the in the time of Spenser, we should see
tracks, leading fro raying out to farms, & to cottages, to
& barns. We should see it like a green oasis in
the middle of a desert. The [close?] It was
It it was [necessary?] If of the great house were to
[detect?] the enemy that it should the enemy, [man?]
that there should was be armour in the church: to
fight against hunger in winter there should be grain in the
barn. The common fight linked the great house to the
small. It is that connection that is detailed
in so many between master & man that is
seen detail detailed so painfully & minutely in the
medieval account books, inventories, that is
so minutely & painfully revealed in the innumerable
in the Paston letters: it makes the staple of
medieval correspondence.
But there was,
also the other connection – there was the
common belief: that bond between the
great house & the small has been obli covered
over. Just as the antiquaries, so that
like the pilgrims way, which is oldtrack

needs.

That was the other bond between the great
house & the cottage. For though the great,
with their with their acga speaking
French as easily as English, with their Latin & Greek
tags on their tongues, despised the
must despise the jargon of the peasant, they
shared the superstitions. An old woman in a
cott hovel was to the King himself even,
the vessel of an unclean spirit. A dun
chicken, she said, sucked on her chin. When the
pilliwinks were applied to her, she confessed
on all Hallows E'en last she with 200
witches had gone to sea, each one in a
riddle a sieve drinking & making merry
till they came to the Kerk of N. Berwick

in

                  Lothian
                 where they landed & danced a

reel. When the Earl of 
                
                  Denby
                  Denbigh
                 died a witch was
[mumbling?] in the corner of his room. She confessed
how she had thrown a cat into the sea &
raised a storm that had sunk the Kings ships.
The great house, then, when the nobles read
the Faery Queen aloud, was connected
with the village by these superstitions, needs, beliefs.

impudent bards. It was at He saw,

But how far was the author in 1570 separate
from Anon the minstrel, the ballad singer?
The past seems to be that, when Spenser
Attached his name to the Fairy Queen, the author of
The Spanish Tragedy left his work si unsigned
This is a sign of the that there were two publics:
the reading, & the playgoing. There is a division
It marks a distinction between two kinds of
writer – two methods, too two attitudes of mind.
If there had been no minstrel, would English literature
had remained a read, a book literature?
No stage, no common art; but always one book to be
read, privately; –

After that I had accomplished & published
divers histories... many noble & divers
semblances of this realm of England came &
demanded me many & oftentimes -" Caxton wrote in
the preface to the Morte d'Arthur... why he "to
represent the history of the said noble King &
conqueror King Arthur & of the Knights with the
history of the Sang Gral & of the death o
ending of the said Arthur"

pages that we hear the anonymous
half conscious voice of anon it
telling his tales to the noble & the peasant:
reminding them of the very old Kings &
Knights who lived went their ways through the
wild woods seeking adventure. When Caxton
[observed?] that Arthur never lived, the noble

ised him that you

The book itself testifies to
to to this double is part In the book itself
Mhe deamer mad iorte valivez Lii
the dream is mixed with reality. It is
del>half fable, half fact. So In WeThe book
It is half fable, half fact. Now Merlin fam
Lay together, yet still viewed [merry?]
ere is London, there is the Archbishop of Canterbury. But as
Merlin casts his enchartments, Morgan Le Fay turns herself into
a stone; & the English roads are but Knights are
riding the roads; the roads lead to castles where
Knights lie [illeg.]; the Four Queens pace on white
mules; the a ship with silver sails down to the
water: the Morgan le Fay turns herself to stone;
the hand rises from the lake holding Excalibur.
Is it a child's story? No, for the The
candour is like a child's; yet it is not a
story told to children. There is evil in the word; love; &
gr sorrow. It tells a The story is the story that we tell. we tell. But
the proportions are different. There is no
perspective. The It has not our perspective
There is reflection; catalogue; dream; the
[illeg.] is very [tableau?]. Like children, the Kings
The catalogue is made after a childs
particularity. And this, But this is the
clear eye that sees so definitively; & the
without exaggeration. For there is
a this limpid [disclosure?] of what was real;
there is no sense of the picturesque; & the
beauty is the in the object, not in the
writers manipulations
"– so he went in & looked searched from
chamber to chamber, & found her bed,
but she was not there; there Balin
looked into a fair little garden, & under a
laurel tree he saw her lie under a
[street?] of green samite, & a Knight with her
& under their heads grass & herbs"...
Then the King looked about the wood...
It is but a childs world; it is a world
before the self consciousness had added any
mirror.
There are men & women
angular, gigantic; freed from something impure; yet
old; sin tarnished; corrupt; in the middle of
the fresh, innocent landscape, remembering;–
par It To follow the Knights & ladies in this
strange pre-historic England is to lose our bearings to
shed many habits of thought; but we after all
this it is not an imprinted fabricated world; it is
behind us still, deep down; & savage, primitive, still
existing ending.
But Of the writer, nothing is known.
He does not exist apart from his book. It is
like the anonymous voice speaking
anonymously; the voice of a very old yet still still
common world, where the story is already known to
the listener, where the listener the listener
the voice of an unknown man, who has been
travelling in strange parts, & comes to the
door, across the marsh, through the flood,
to remind the noble & the peasant of what
he has heard long ago.
XVII
In the great house & in the cottage this half articulate
anonymous voice murmured of old Gods, & Kings, & Knights
& Ladies. The well & the tree were still
haunted. King arthur the traveller tell
that about noon, or about midnight, when the
moon is full & shining, they often see an assay of
hawkers with dogs & sound of horses, who, in
answer to the [enquiries?] say that they are
of the [homestead?] & fellowship of Arthur."
Along the roads from town to town, from one
great house to another came the [mummers?] & the
rhymers, the jugglers the bear leaders, the
makers of ballads, the fo while for these
who could read it & hear it, Caxton
book told the story of Arthur.
Then, the instinct to enact, to impersonate
what they see heard came into being. Even the King &
Queen must have their minstrels to give shape
to this hidden instinct. The author was
despised: the for he displayed his body: after,
because, feeling himself an outcast, he used the

                 to of irresponsible
mockery. Yet just as we tolerate those who
say  what we are too proud to admit, the
minstrel was tolerated. Even the churchmen,
aware that the other gods than his were
being worshipped, mus could not suppress the
actor. When he was no longer If they could,
they constrained the juggler & the dancer
to put off their leaves & their bells & to
robe themselves as the [pilgrimages?] in a miracle
play. But when the old pl story religious
story was stale, they left played in the
[courtyard? churchyard?], & at last set up their pageant in the
market place.
